Personalized Federated Learning through Local Memorization

Othmane Marfoq â€ƒâ€ƒ Giovanni Neglia â€ƒâ€ƒ Laetitia Kameni â€ƒâ€ƒ Richard Vidal
Abstract

Federated learning allows clients to collaboratively learn statistical models while keeping their data local. Federated learning was originally used to train a unique global model to be served to all clients, but this approach might be sub-optimal when clientsâ€™ local data distributions are heterogeneous. In order to tackle this limitation, recent personalized federated learning methods train a separate model for each client while still leveraging the knowledge available at other clients. In this work, we exploit the ability of deep neural networks to extract high quality vectorial representations (embeddings) from non-tabular data, e.g., images and text, to propose a personalization mechanism based on local memorization. Personalization is obtained by interpolating a collectively trained global model with a local kğ‘˜k-nearest neighbors (kNN) model based on the shared representation provided by the global model. We provide generalization bounds for the proposed approach in the case of binary classification, and we show on a suite of federated datasets that this approach achieves significantly higher accuracy and fairness than state-of-the-art methods.

Machine Learning, Federated Learning

1 Introduction

Heterogeneity is a core and fundamental challenge in Federated Learning (FL)Â (Li etÂ al., 2020; Kairouz etÂ al., 2019). Indeed, clients highly differ both in size and distribution of their local datasets (statistical heterogeneity), and in their storage and computational capabilities (system heterogeneity). Those two aspects challenge the assumption that clients should train a common global model, as pursued in many federated learning papers (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; KoneÄny etÂ al., 2016; Sahu etÂ al., 2018; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020; Mohri etÂ al., 2019). In fact, all clients should be content with a modelâ€™s architecture constrained by the minimum common capabilities. Even when clients have similar hardware (e.g., they are all smartphones), in presence of statistical heterogeneity, a global model may be arbitrarily bad for some clients raising important fairness concernsÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021).

Motivated by the recent success of memorization techniques based on nearest neighbours for natural language processing, Â (Khandelwal etÂ al., 2019, 2020), computer visionÂ (Papernot and McDaniel, 2018; Orhan, 2018), and few-shot classificationÂ (Snell etÂ al., 2017; Wang etÂ al., 2019), we propose kNN-Per, a personalized FL algorithm based on local memorization. kNN-Per combines a global model trained collectively (e.g., via FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017)) with a kNN model on a clientâ€™s local datastore. The global model also provides the shared representation used by the local kNN. Local memorization at each FL client can capture the clientâ€™s local distribution shift with respect to the global distribution. Indeed, our experiments show that memorization is more beneficial when the distribution shift is larger. The generalization bound in Sec.Â 3 contributes to justify our empirical findings as well as those in (Khandelwal etÂ al., 2019, 2020; Orhan, 2018).

kNN-Per offers a simple and effective way to address statistical heterogeneity even in a dynamic environment where clientâ€™s data distributions change after training. It is indeed sufficient to update the local datastore with new data without the need to retrain the global model. Moreover, each client can independently tune the local kNN to its storage and computing capabilities, partially relieving the most powerful clients from the need to align their model to the weakest ones. Finally, kNN-Per has a limited leakage of private information, as personalization only occurs once communication exchanges have ended, and, if needed, it can be easily combined with differential privacy techniques.

Our contributions are threefold: 1) we propose kNN-Per, a simple personalization mechanism based on local memorization; 2) we provide generalization bounds for the proposed approach in the case of binary classification; 3) through extensive experiments on FL benchmarks, we show that kNN-Per achieves significantly higher accuracy and fairness than state-of-the-art methods.

The paper is organized as follows. After an overview of related work in Sec.Â 2, we present kNN-Per in Sec.Â 3 and provide generalization bounds in Sec.Â 4. Experimental setup and results are described in Sec.Â 5 and Sec.Â 6, respectively.

2 Related Work

We discuss personalized FL approaches to address statistical heterogeneity and system heterogeneity as well as nearest neighbours augmented neural networks.

2.1 Statistical Heterogeneity

This body of work considers that all clients have the same model architecture but potentially different parameters.

A simple approach for FL personalization is learning first a global model and then fine-tuning its parameters at each client through stochastic gradient descent for a few epochsÂ (Jiang etÂ al., 2019; Yu etÂ al., 2020); we refer later to this approach as FedAvg+. FedAvg+ was later studied by Chen and Chao (2022) and Cheng etÂ al. (2021). The global model can then be considered as a meta-model to be used as initialization for a few-shot adaptation at each client. Later workÂ (Khodak etÂ al., 2019; Fallah etÂ al., 2020; Acar etÂ al., 2021) has formally established the connection with Model Agnostic Meta Learning (MAML)Â (Jiang etÂ al., 2019) and proposed different algorithms to train a more suitable meta-model for local personalization.

ClusteredFLÂ (Sattler etÂ al., 2020; Ghosh etÂ al., 2020; Mansour etÂ al., 2020) assumes that clients can be partitioned into several clusters, with clients in the same cluster sharing the same model, while models can be arbitrarily different across clusters. Clients jointly learn during training the cluster to which they belong as well as the cluster model. FedEM Â (Marfoq etÂ al., 2021) can be considered as a soft clustering algorithm as clients learn personalized models as mixtures of a limited number of component models.

Multi-Task Learning (MTL) allows for more nuanced relations among clientsâ€™ models by defining federated MTL as a penalized optimization problem, where the penalization term captures clientsâ€™ dissimilarity. Seminal work (Smith etÂ al., 2017; Vanhaesebrouck etÂ al., 2017; Zantedeschi etÂ al., 2020) proposed algorithms able to deal with quite generic penalization terms, at the cost of learning only linear models or linear combinations of pre-trained models. Other MTL-based algorithmsÂ (Hanzely and RichtÃ¡rik, 2020; Hanzely etÂ al., 2020; T.Â Dinh etÂ al., 2020; Dinh etÂ al., 2021; Li etÂ al., 2021; Huang etÂ al., 2021; Li etÂ al., 2021) are able to train more general models but consider simpler penalization terms (e.g., the distance to the average model).

An alternative approach is to interpolate a global model and one local model per clientÂ (Deng etÂ al., 2020; Corinzia and Buhmann, 2019; Mansour etÂ al., 2020). Zhang etÂ al. (2021) extended this idea by letting each client interpolate the local models of other clients with opportune weights learned during training. Our algorithm, kNN-Per, also interpolates a global and a local model, but the global model plays a double role as it is also used to provide a useful representation for the local kNN.

Closer to our approach, FedRepÂ (Collins etÂ al., 2021), FedPerÂ (Arivazhagan etÂ al., 2019), and pFedGP (Achituve etÂ al., 2021) jointly learn a global latent representation and local modelsâ€”linear models for FedRep and FedPer, Gaussian processes for pFedGPâ€”that operate on top of this representation. In these algorithms, the progressive refinement of local models affects the shared representation. On the contrary, in kNN-Per only the global model (and then the shared representation) is the object of federated training, and the shared representation is not influenced by local models, which are learned separately by each client in a second moment. Our experiments suggest that kNN-Perâ€™s approach is more efficient. A possible explanation is that jointly learning the shared representation and the local models lead to potentially conflicting and interfering goals. A similar argument was provided by Li etÂ al. (2021) to justify why Ditto replaces, as penalization term, the distance from the average of the local modelsâ€”as proposed inÂ (Hanzely and RichtÃ¡rik, 2020; Hanzely etÂ al., 2020; T.Â Dinh etÂ al., 2020)â€”with the distance from an independently learned global model. Liang etÂ al. (2020) proposed a someway opposite approach to FedRep, FedPer, and pFedGP by using local representations as input to a global model, but the representations and the global model are still jointly learned. An additional advantage of kNN-Perâ€™s clear separation between global and local model training is that, because each client does not share any information about its local model with the server, the risk of leaking private information is reduced. In particular, kNN-Per enjoys the same privacy guarantees as FedAvg, and can be easily combined with differential privacy techniques (Wei etÂ al., 2020).

To the best of our knowledge, pFedGP and kNN-Per are the first attempts to learn semi-parametric modelsÂ (Bickel etÂ al., 1998) in a federated setting. pFedGP relies on Gaussian processes and then has higher computational cost than kNN-Per both at training and inference.

2.2 System Heterogeneity

Some FL application scenarios envision clients with highly heterogeneous hardware, like smartphones, IoT devices, edge computing servers, and the cloud. Ideally, each client could learn a potentially different model architecture, suited to its capabilities. Such system heterogeneity has been studied much less than statistical heterogeneity.

Some workÂ (Lin etÂ al., 2020; Li and Wang, 2019; Zhu etÂ al., 2021; Zhang and Yuan, 2021) proposed to address system heterogeneity by distilling the knowledge from a global teacher to clientsâ€™ student models with different architectures. While early methods (Li and Wang, 2019; Lin etÂ al., 2020) required the access to an extra (unlabeled) public dataset, more recent ones (Zhu etÂ al., 2021; Zhang and Yuan, 2021) eliminated this requirement.

Some papers (Diao etÂ al., 2020; HorvÃ¡th etÂ al., 2021; Pilet etÂ al., 2021) propose that each client only trains a sub-model of a global model. The sub-model size is determined by the clientâ€™s computational capabilities. The approach appears particularly advantageous for convolutional neural networks with clients selecting only a limited subset of channels.

Tan etÂ al. (2022) followed another approach where devices and server communicate prototypes, i.e., average representations for all samples in a given class, instead of communicating modelâ€™s gradients or parameters, allowing each client to have a different model architecture and input space.

While in this paper we assume that kNN-Per relies on a shared global model, it is possible to replace it with heterogeneous models adapted to the clientsâ€™ capabilities and jointly trained following one of the methods listed above. Then, kNN-Perâ€™s interpolation with a kNN model extends these methods to address not only system heterogeneity, but also statistical heterogeneity.

To the best of our knowledge, the only existing method that takes into account both system and statistical heterogeneity is pFedHNÂ (Shamsian etÂ al., 2021). pFedHN feeds local clients representations to a global (across clients) hypernetwork, which can output personalized heterogeneous models. Unfortunately, the hypernetwork has a large memory footprint already for small clientsâ€™ models (e.g., the hypernetwork in the experiments inÂ (Shamsian etÂ al., 2021) has 100 more parameters than the output model): it is not clear if pFedHN can scale to complex models.

We observe that kNN-Perâ€™s kNN model can itself be adapted to clientâ€™s capabilities by tuning the size of the datastore and/or selecting an appropriate approximate kNN algorithm, like FAISS (Johnson etÂ al., 2019), HNSW (Malkov and Yashunin, 2020), or ProtoNNÂ (Gupta etÂ al., 2017) for IoT resource-scarce devices, e.g., based on Arduino.

2.3 Nearest Neighbours Augmented Neural Networks

Recent work proposed to augment neural networks with nearest neighbours classifiers for applications to language modellingÂ (Khandelwal etÂ al., 2019), neural machine translationÂ (Khandelwal etÂ al., 2020), computer visionÂ (Papernot and McDaniel, 2018; Orhan, 2018), and few-shot learningÂ (Snell etÂ al., 2017; Wang etÂ al., 2019).

InÂ (Khandelwal etÂ al., 2019, 2020) kNN improves model performance by memorizing explicitly (rather than implicitly in model parameters) rare patterns. Papernot and McDaniel (2018) and Orhan (2018) showed that memorization can also increase the robustness of models against adversarial attacks. Differently from these lines of work, our paper shows that local memorization at each FL client can capture the clientâ€™s local distribution shift with respect to the global distribution. In this sense, our use of kNN is more similar to what is proposed for few shot learning inÂ (Snell etÂ al., 2017; Wang etÂ al., 2019), where an embedding function is learned for future application to new small datasets. Beside the different learning problem, the algorithms proposed inÂ (Snell etÂ al., 2017; Wang etÂ al., 2019) do not rely on modelsâ€™ interpolation and do not enjoy generalization guarantees as kNN-Per does. Moreover, their natural extension to the FL setting would lead to jointly learn the shared representation and the local kNN models, a potentially less efficient approach than ours as we discussed above when presenting FedRep, and pFedGP.

The parameter Î»msubscriptğœ†ğ‘š\lambda_{m} is tuned at clientÂ mğ‘šm through a local validation dataset or cross-validation as inÂ (Corinzia and Buhmann, 2019; Mansour etÂ al., 2020; Zhang etÂ al., 2021; Li etÂ al., 2021). Clients could also use different values kmsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘šk_{m} and different distance metrics dmâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘šâ‹…d_{m}(\cdot), but, in what follows, we consider them equal across clients. Also our experiments in Sec.Â 6 show that kğ‘˜k and dâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘‘â‹…d(\cdot) do not require careful tuning.

4 Generalization Bounds

In this section we provide a generalization bound associated with the proposed approach in the case of binary classification, namely ğ’´={0,1}ğ’´01\mathcal{Y}=\left\{0,1\right\}, when only one neighbour is used for kNN estimation, i.e., k=1ğ‘˜1k=1, and dâ€‹(â‹…,â‹…)ğ‘‘â‹…â‹…d\left(\cdot,\cdot\right) is the Euclidean distance. Assumption 1 (Bounded representation).

Remark 1.

Loss boundedness is a common assumption, e.g., (Mansour etÂ al., 2020),(Shalev-Shwartz and Ben-David, 2014, Ch.Â 4). The second requirement is that the maximum loss is achieved when the model is fully confident about a prediction, but this is wrong. A simple transformation of common loss functionsâ€”e.g., exponentiating the logistic functionâ€”make them satisfy AssumptionÂ 2.

Assumption 3 (Loss convexity).

We observe that, when clients only use the global model (Î»m=0subscriptğœ†ğ‘š0\lambda_{m}=0), our generalization bound is analogous to the probabilistic bound in (Mansour etÂ al., 2020, Eq.Â (2)). The boundÂ (4.1) leads to predict that client mğ‘šm should give a larger weight (Î»m>1/2subscriptğœ†ğ‘š12\lambda_{m}>1/2) to its kNN model, when nmsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘šn_{m} exceeds a given threshold, even when local distributions are identical. The bound contributes then to explain why adding a memorization mechanism on top of a pretrained model can improve performance, as observed in (Khandelwal etÂ al., 2019) and (Khandelwal etÂ al., 2020). While it is difficult to quantify the threshold analytically (also because the constants involved depend on Î³1subscriptğ›¾1\gamma_{1} and Î³2subscriptğ›¾2\gamma_{2} in AssumptionÂ 4), our experiments in Sec.Â 6 show that even clients with a few tens of samples weigh more the kNN model than the global one.

5 Experimental Setup

We evaluate kNN-Per on four federated datasets spanning a wide range of machine learning tasks: language modeling (Shakespeare (Caldas etÂ al., 2018; McMahan etÂ al., 2017)), image classification (CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 (Krizhevsky, 2009)), handwritten character recognition (FEMNIST (Caldas etÂ al., 2018)). Unless otherwise said, kNN-Perâ€™s global model hğ’®subscriptâ„ğ’®h_{\mathcal{S}} is trained by all clients through FedAvg. Code is available at https://github.com/omarfoq/knn-per.

Datasets. For Shakespeare and FEMNIST datasets there is a natural way to partition data through clients (by character and by writer, respectively). We relied on common approaches in the literature to sample heterogenous local datasets from CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100. We created a federated version of CIFAR-10 by randomly partitioning the dataset among clients using a symmetric Dirichlet distribution, as done in (Wang etÂ al., 2020). In particular, for each label yğ‘¦y we sampled a vector pysubscriptğ‘ğ‘¦p_{y} from a Dirichlet distribution of order M=200ğ‘€200M=200 and parameter Î±=0.3ğ›¼0.3\alpha=0.3 (unless otherwise specified) and allocated to client mğ‘šm a py,msubscriptğ‘ğ‘¦ğ‘šp_{y,m} fraction of all training instances of class yğ‘¦y. The approach ensures that the number of data points and label distributions are unbalanced across clients. For CIFAR-100, we exploit the availability of â€œcoarseâ€ and â€œfineâ€ label structure, to partition the dataset using pachinko allocation method (Li and McCallum, 2006) as in (Reddi etÂ al., 2021). The method generates local datasets with heterogeneous distributions by combining a per-client Dirichlet distribution with parameter Î±=0.3ğ›¼0.3\alpha=0.3 (unless otherwise specified) over the coarse labels and a per-coarse-label Dirichlet distribution with parameter Î²=10ğ›½10\beta=10 over the corresponding fine labels. We also partitioned CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 in a different way following (Achituve etÂ al., 2021): each client has only samples from two and ten classes for CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100, respectively. We refer to the resulting datasets as CIFAR-10 (v2) and CIFAR-100 (v2). For FEMNIST and Shakespeare, we randomly split each local dataset into training (60%percent6060\%), validation (20%percent2020\%), and test (20%percent2020\%) sets. For CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100, we maintained the original training/test data split and used 20%percent2020\% of the training dataset as validation dataset. TableÂ 1 summarizes datasets, models and number of clients.

Models and representations. For CIFAR-100, CIFAR-10, and FEMNIST, we used MobileNet-v2 (Sandler etÂ al., 2018) as a base model with the output of the last hidden layerâ€”a 128012801280-dimensional vectorâ€”as representation. For Shakespeare, the base model was a stacked LSTM model with two layers, each of them with 256256256 units; a 102410241024-dimensional representation was obtained by concatenating the hidden states and the cell states.

Benchmarks. We compared kNN-Per with locally trained models (with no collaboration across clients) and FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), as well as with one method for each of the personalization approaches described in Sec.Â 2, namely, FedAvg+Â (Jiang etÂ al., 2019),333 We also implemented the more sophisticated first-order MAML approach fromÂ (Fallah etÂ al., 2020), but had worse performance than FedAvg+. ClusteredFLÂ (Sattler etÂ al., 2020), DittoÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021), FedRepÂ (Collins etÂ al., 2021), APFLÂ (Deng etÂ al., 2020), and pFedGPÂ (Achituve etÂ al., 2021).444 We were able to run the official pFedGPâ€™s code (https://github.com/IdanAchituve/pFedGP) only on datasets partitioned as inÂ (Achituve etÂ al., 2021). For each method, and each dataset, we tuned the learning rate via grid search on the values {10âˆ’0.5,10âˆ’1,10âˆ’1.5,10âˆ’2,10âˆ’2.5}superscript100.5superscript101superscript101.5superscript102superscript102.5\left\{10^{-0.5},10^{-1},10^{-1.5},10^{-2},10^{-2.5}\right\}. FedPerâ€™s learning rate for network headsâ€™ training was separately tuned on the same grid. Dittoâ€™s penalization parameter Î»msubscriptğœ†ğ‘š\lambda_{m} was selected among the values {101,100,10âˆ’1,10âˆ’2}superscript101superscript100superscript101superscript102\left\{10^{1},10^{0},10^{-1},10^{-2}\right\} on a per-client basis. For ClusteredFL, we used the same values of tolerance specified in its official implementation (Sattler etÂ al., 2020). We found tuning tol1 and tol2 particularly hard: no empirical rule is provided in (Sattler etÂ al., 2020), and the few random settings we tried did not show any improvement in comparison to the default ones. For APFL, the mixing parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha was tuned via grid search on the grid {0.1,0.3,0.5,0.7,0.9}0.10.30.50.70.9\left\{0.1,0.3,0.5,0.7,0.9\right\}. For pFedGP, we used the same hyperparameters as in (Achituve etÂ al., 2021). The parameterÂ Î»msubscriptğœ†ğ‘š\lambda_{m} of kNN-Per was tuned for each client via grid search on the grid {0.0,0.1,0.3,0.5,0.7,0.9,1.0}0.00.10.30.50.70.91.0\left\{0.0,0.1,0.3,0.5,0.7,0.9,1.0\right\}, and the number of neighbours was set to k=10ğ‘˜10k=10. Once the optimal hyperparametersâ€™ values were selected, models were retrained on the concatenation of training and validation sets.

Training details. In all experiments with CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100, training spanned 200200200 rounds with full clientsâ€™ participation at each round for all methods. The learning rate was reduced by a factor 101010 at round 100100100 and then again at round 150150150. For Shakespeare, 10%percent1010\% of clients were sampled uniformly at random without replacement at each round, and we trained for 300300300 rounds with a constant learning rate. For FEMNIST, 5%percent55\% of the clients participated at each round for a total 100010001000 rounds, with the learning rate dropping by a factor 101010 at round 500500500 and 750750750. In all our experiments we employed the following aggregation scheme

ğ°t+1=âˆ‘mâˆ‰ğ•Štnmnâ€‹ğ°t+âˆ‘mâˆˆğ•Štnmnâ€‹ğ°tm,subscriptğ°ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ•Šğ‘¡subscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘›subscriptğ°ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ•Šğ‘¡subscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘š\mathbf{w}_{t+1}=\sum_{m\notin\mathbb{S}_{t}}\frac{n_{m}}{n}\mathbf{w}_{t}+\sum_{m\in\mathbb{S}_{t}}\frac{n_{m}}{n}\mathbf{w}_{t}^{m}, (13)

In all our experiments, local hypotheses follow Eq.Â (3) with dâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘‘â‹…d(\cdot) being the Euclidean distance. kNN retrieval relied on FAISS libraryÂ (Johnson etÂ al., 2019).

6 Experiments

Average performance of personalized models. The performance of each personalized model (which coincides with the global one in the case of FedAvg) is evaluated on the local test dataset (unseen at training). TableÂ 2 shows the average weighted accuracy with weights proportional to local dataset sizes. kNN-Per consistently achieves the highest accuracy across all datasets. We observe that Local performs much worse than any other FL method as expected (e.g., 25 pp w.r.t.Â kNN-Per or 22 pp w.r.t. Â to Ditto on CIFAR-10). Local outperforms some other FL methods on CIFAR-10/100 (v2). This splitting was proposed in pFedGPâ€™s paperâ€”where the same result is observed (Achituve etÂ al., 2021, TableÂ 1). This occurs because each client only receives samples for a few classes, and then its local task is much easier than the global one.

Fairness across clients. TableÂ 2 also shows the bottom decile of the accuracy of personalized models, i.e., the (M/10ğ‘€10M/10)-th worst accuracy (the minimum accuracy is particularly noisy, notably because some local test datasets are very small). We observe that even clients with the worst personalized models are still better off when kNN-Per is used for training.

Generalization to unseen clients. An advantage of kNN-Per is that a â€œnewâ€ client arriving after training may easily learn a personalized model: it may simply retrieve the global model (whose training it did not participate to) from the orchestrator and use it to build the local datastore for kNN. Even if this scenario was not explicitly considered in their original papers, other personalized FL methods can also be adapted to new clients as follows. FedAvg++ personalizes the global model through stochastic gradient updates on the new clientâ€™s local dataset. Ditto operates similarly, but maintains a penalization term proportional to the distance between the personalized model and the global model. FedRep trains the network head using the local dataset, while freezing the body as in the global model. For pFedGP new clients inherit the previously trained shared network and compute their local kernel. ClusteredFL assigns the new client to one learned cluster model using a held-out validation set. In the case of FedAvg, there is no personalization and the new client uses directly the global model. We performed an experiment where only 80%percent8080\% of the clients participated to the training and the remaining 20%percent2020\% joined later. Results in TableÂ 3 show that, despite its simplicity in dealing with new clients, kNN-Per still outperforms all other methods.

Effect of local datasetâ€™s size. Beside its relevance for some practical scenarios, the distinction between old and new clients also helps us to evaluate how different factors contribute to the final performance of kNN-Per. For example, to understand how the size of the local dataset affects performance, we reduced proportionally the size of new clientsâ€™ local datasets, while maintaining unchanged the global model, which was trained on old clients. FigureÂ 1 shows that new clients still reap most of kNN-Perâ€™s benefits even if their local datastore is reduced by a factor 3. Note that if we had changed the local dataset sizes also for old clients, the global model (and then the representation) would have changed too, making it difficult to isolate the effect of the local datastore size. We show the results for this experiment in FigureÂ 6 (AppendixÂ B).

Effect of data heterogeneity. FigureÂ 1 also shows that, as expected by TheoremÂ 4.1, the benefit of the memorization mechanism is larger when data distributions are more heterogeneous (smaller Î±ğ›¼\alpha). While other methods also benefit from higher heterogeneity, kNN-Per appears to address statistical heterogeneity more effectively (FigureÂ 10). Note that if local distributions were identical (Î±â†’âˆâ†’ğ›¼\alpha\to\infty), no personalization method would provide any advantage.

Hyperparameters. kNN-Perâ€™s performance is not highly sensitive to the value kğ‘˜k which can be selected between 777 andÂ 141414 for CIFAR-10 and between 555 and 121212 for CIFAR-100 with less than 0.2 percentage points of accuracy variation (see FigureÂ 5 in AppendixÂ B). Similarly, scaling the Euclidean distance by a factor Ïƒğœ\sigma has almost no effect for values of Ïƒğœ\sigma between 0.10.10.1 and 100100100 and between 111 and 100100100, respectively for CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 (see FigureÂ 7 in AppendixÂ B). The interpolation parameter Î»msubscriptğœ†ğ‘š\lambda_{m} plays a more important role. Experiments in AppendixÂ B (FigureÂ 8) show that, as expected, the larger the local dataset, the more clients rely on the local kNN model. Interestingly, clients give a larger weight to the kNN model than to the global one (Î»>1/2ğœ†12\lambda>1/2) for datasets with just one hundred samples (FigureÂ 2).

Effect of global modelâ€™s quality. AssumptionÂ 4 stipulates that the smaller the expected loss of the global model, the better representationsâ€™ distances capture the variability of ğ±â†¦ğ’Ÿm(â‹…|ğ±)\mathbf{x}\mapsto\mathcal{D}_{m}\left(\cdot|\mathbf{x}\right) and then the more accurate the kNN model. This effect is quantified by LemmaÂ A.2, where the loss of the local memorization mechanism is upper bounded by a term that depends linearly on the loss of the global model. In order to validate this assumption, we study the relation between the test accuracies of the global model and kNN-Per. In particular, we trained a global model for CIFAR-10, in a centralized way, and we save the weights at different stages of the training, leading to global models with different accuracy. FigureÂ 3 shows the test accuracy of kNN-Per with Î»=1ğœ†1\lambda=1 (i.e., when only the kNN predictor is used) as a function of the global modelâ€™s test accuracy for different levels of heterogeneity. We observe that, quite unexpectedly, the relation between the two accuracies is almost linear. Additional experiments (also including CIFAR-100) in AppendixÂ B confirm these findings.

Robustness to distribution shift.

kNN-Per offers a simple and effective way to address statistical heterogeneity in a dynamic environment where clientâ€™s data distributions change after training. We simulate such a dynamic environment as follows. Client mğ‘šm initially has a datastore with instances sampled from data distribution ğ’Ÿmsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘š\mathcal{D}_{m}. At each time step t<t0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0t<t_{0}, client mğ‘šm receives a batch of instances drawn from ğ’Ÿmsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘š\mathcal{D}_{m}. At time step t0subscriptğ‘¡0t_{0}, a data distribution shift takes place, i.e., for t0â‰¤tâ‰¤Tsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡t_{0}\leq t\leq T, client mğ‘šm receives instances drawn from a data distribution ğ’Ÿmâ€²â‰ ğ’Ÿmsuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘šâ€²subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘š\mathcal{D}_{m}^{\prime}\neq\mathcal{D}_{m}. Upon receiving new instances, client mğ‘šm may use those instances to update its datastore. We consider 333 different strategies: (1) first-in-first-out (FIFO) where, at time step tğ‘¡t, new instances replace the oldest ones; (2) concatenate, where the new samples are simply added to the datastore; (3) fixed datastore, where the datastore is not updated at all. FigureÂ 4 shows the evaluation of the test accuracy across time. If clients do not update their datastores, there is a significant drop in accuracy as soon as the distribution changes at t0=50subscriptğ‘¡050t_{0}=50. Under FIFO, we observe some random fluctuations for the accuracy for t<t0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0t<t_{0}, as repository changes affect the kNN predictions. While accuracy inevitably drops for t=t0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0t=t_{0}, it then increases as datastores are progressively populated by instances from the new distributions. Under the â€œconcatenateâ€ strategy, results are similar, but 1)Â accuracy increases for t<t0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0t<t_{0} as the quality of kNN predictors improves for larger datastores, 2) accuracy increases also for t>t0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0t>t_{0}, but at a slower pace than what observed under FIFO, as samples from the old distribution are never evicted. Experimentsâ€™ details and results for CIFAR-100 are in AppendixÂ B.

AppendixÂ B also includes experiments to evaluate the effect of system heterogeneity and the possibility to use aggressive nearest neighbours compression techniques like ProtoNNÂ (Gupta etÂ al., 2017).

7 Conclusion

In this paper, we showed that local memorization at each client is a simple and effective way to address statistical heterogeneity in federated learning. In particular, while a global model trained with classic FL techniques, like FedAvg, may not deliver accurate predictions at each client, it may still provide a good representation of the input, which can be advantageously used by a local kNN model. This finding suggests that combining memorization techniques with neural networks has additional benefits other than those highlighted in the seminal papersÂ (Grefenstette etÂ al., 2015; Joulin and Mikolov, 2015) and the recent applications to natural language processingÂ (Khandelwal etÂ al., 2019, 2020).

The better performance of kNN-Per in comparison to FedRep and pFedGP show that jointly learning the shared representation and the local models (as FedRep and pFedGP do) may lead to potentially conflicting and interfering goals, but further study is required to understand this interaction. Semi-parametric learningÂ (Bickel etÂ al., 1993) could be the right framework to formalize this problem, but its extension to a federated setting is still unexplored.

Appendix A Proofs

In the general description of kNN-Per, and in our experiments, we considered that each client mâˆˆ[M]ğ‘šdelimited-[]ğ‘€m\in[M] uses its whole dataset ğ’®msubscriptğ’®ğ‘š\mathcal{S}_{m} both to train the base shared model hğ’®subscriptâ„ğ’®h_{\mathcal{S}}â€”and the corresponding representation function Ï•hğ’®subscriptitalic-Ï•subscriptâ„ğ’®\phi_{h_{\mathcal{S}}}â€”and to populate the local datastore.

A.2 Intermediate Lemmas

Lemma A.1.

Appendix B Additional Experiments

Effect of kernel scale parameter Ïƒğœ\sigma.

We consider distance metrics of the form

âˆ€ğ³,ğ³â€²âˆˆâ„p;dÏƒâ€‹(ğ³,ğ³â€²)=â€–ğ³âˆ’ğ³â€²â€–2Ïƒ,formulae-sequencefor-allğ³superscriptğ³â€²superscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptğ‘‘ğœğ³superscriptğ³â€²subscriptnormğ³superscriptğ³â€²2ğœ\forall\mathbf{z},\mathbf{z}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{p};~{}d_{\sigma}\left(\mathbf{z},\mathbf{z}^{\prime}\right)=\frac{\left\|\mathbf{z}-\mathbf{z^{\prime}}\right\|_{2}}{\sigma}, (40)

where Ïƒâˆˆâ„+ğœsuperscriptâ„\sigma\in\mathbb{R}^{+} is a scale parameter. FigureÂ 7 shows that kNN-Perâ€™s performance is not highly sensitive to the selection of the length scale parameter, as scaling the Euclidean distance by a constant factor Ïƒğœ\sigma has almost no effect for values of Ïƒğœ\sigma between 0.10.10.1 and 100010001000.

Effect of datastoreâ€™s size on the optimal Î»ğœ†\lambda.

FigureÂ 8 shows the effect of the local number of samples nmsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘šn_{m} on the optimal mixing parameter Î»optsubscriptğœ†opt\lambda_{\text{opt}} (evaluated on the clientâ€™s test dataset). The number of samples changes across clients and, for the same client, with different values of the capacity. The figure shows a positive correlation between the local number of samples and the optimal mixing parameter and then validates the intuition that clients with more samples tend to rely more on the memorization mechanism than on the base model, as captured by the generalization bound from TheoremÂ 4.1.

Effect of hardware heterogeneity.

In our experiments above, clientsâ€™ local datasets had different size, which can also be due to different memory capabilities. In order to investigate more in depth the effect of system heterogeneity, we split the new clients in two groups: â€œweakâ€ clients with normalized capacity 1/2âˆ’Î”â€‹C12Î”ğ¶1/2-\Delta C and â€œstrongâ€ clients with normalized capacity 1/2+Î”â€‹C12Î”ğ¶1/2+\Delta C, where Î”â€‹Câˆˆ(0,1/2)Î”ğ¶012\Delta C\in(0,1/2) is a parameter controlling the hardware heterogeneity of the system. Note that the total amount of memory in the system is constant, but varying Î”â€‹CÎ”ğ¶\Delta C changes its distribution across clients from a homogeneous scenario (Î”â€‹C=0Î”ğ¶0\Delta C=0) to an extremely heterogeneous one (Î”â€‹C=0.5Î”ğ¶0.5\Delta C=0.5). FigureÂ 10 shows the effect of the hardware heterogeneity, as captured by Î”â€‹CÎ”ğ¶\Delta C. As the marginal improvement from additional memory is decreasing (see, e.g., Fig.Â 1) the gain for strong clients does not compensate the loss for weak ones. The overall effect is then that the average test accuracy decreases as system heterogeneity increases.

Adding compression techniques.

kNN-Per can be combined with nearest neighbours compression techniques as ProtoNN [Gupta etÂ al., 2017]. ProtoNN reduces the amount of memory required by jointly learning 1) a small number of prototypes to represent the entire training set and 2) a data projection into a low dimensional space. We combined kNN-Per and ProtoNN and explored both the effect of the number of prototypes and the projection dimension used in ProtoNN. For each client, the number of prototypes is set to a given fraction of the total number of available samples. We refer to this quantity also as capacity. We varied the capacity in the grid {iÃ—10âˆ’1,iâˆˆ[10]}ğ‘–superscript101ğ‘–delimited-[]10\{i\times 10^{-1},i\in[10]\}, and the projection dimension in the grid {iÃ—100,iâˆˆ[12]}âˆª{1280}ğ‘–100ğ‘–delimited-[]121280\{i\times 100,i\in[12]\}\cup\{1280\}. Note that smaller projection dimension and less prototypes correspond to a smaller memory footprint, suited for more restricted hardware. Our implementation is based on ProtoNNâ€™s official.555 https://github.com/Microsoft/EdgeML. FigureÂ 11(a) shows that, on CIFAR-10, ProtoNN allows to reduce the kNN-Perâ€™s memory footprint by a factor four (using nm/3subscriptğ‘›ğ‘š3n_{m}/3 prototypes and projection dimension 100010001000) at the cost of a limited reduction in test accuracy (82.3%percent82.382.3\% versus 83.0%percent83.083.0\% in TableÂ 2). Note that kNN-Per with ProtoNN still outperforms all other methods. On CIFAR-100, ProtoNNâ€™s compression techniques appear less advantageous: the approach loses about 3 percentage points (52.1%percent52.152.1\% versus 55.0%percent55.055.0\% in TableÂ 2) while only reducing memory requirement by 20%percent2020\%.

Effect of global modelâ€™s quality.

AssumptionÂ 4 stipulates that the smaller the expected loss of the global model, the more accurate the corresponding representation. As representation quality improves, we can expect that kNN accuracy improves too. This effect is quantified by LemmaÂ A.2, where the loss of the local memorization mechanism is upper bounded by a term that depends linearly on the loss of the global model. In order to validate this assumption, we study the relation between the test accuracies of the global model and kNN-Per. In particular, we train two global models, one for CIFAR-10 and the other for CIFAR-100, in a centralized way, and we save the weights at different stages of the training, leading to global models with different qualities. FigureÂ 12 shows the test accuracy of kNN-Per with Î»=1ğœ†1\lambda=1 (i.e., when only the knn predictor is used) as a function of the global modelâ€™s test accuracy for different levels of heterogeneity on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets. We observe that, quite unexpectedly, the relation between the two accuracies is almost linear. The experiments also confirm what observed in Fig.Â 1: kNN-Perperforms better when local distributions are more heterogeneous (smaller Î±ğ›¼\alpha). Similar plots with Î»ğœ†\lambda optimized locally at every client are shown in Fig.Â 13.

Robustness to distribution shift.

As previously mentioned, kNN-Per offers a simple and effective way to address statistical heterogeneity in a dynamic environment where clientâ€™s data distributions change after training. We simulate such a dynamic environment as follows. Client mğ‘šm initially has a datastore built using instances sampled from a data distribution ğ’Ÿmsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘š\mathcal{D}_{m}. For time step t<t0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0t<t_{0}, client mğ‘šm receives a batch of nm(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘¡n_{m}^{(t)} instances drawn from ğ’Ÿmsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘š\mathcal{D}_{m}. At time step t0subscriptğ‘¡0t_{0}, we suppose that a data distribution shift takes place, i.e., for t0â‰¤tâ‰¤Tsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡t_{0}\leq t\leq T, client mğ‘šm receives nm(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘¡n_{m}^{(t)} instances drawn from a data distribution ğ’Ÿmâ€²â‰ ğ’Ÿmsuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘šâ€²subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘š\mathcal{D}_{m}^{\prime}\neq\mathcal{D}_{m}. Upon receiving new instances, client mğ‘šm may use those instances to update its datastore. We consider 333 different strategies: (1) first-in-first-out (FIFO) where, at time step tğ‘¡t, the nm(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘¡n_{m}^{(t)} oldest samples are replaced by the newly obtained samples; (2) concatenate, where the new samples are simply added to the datastore; (3) fixed datastore, where the datastore is not updated at all. In our simulations, we consider CIFAR-10/100 datasets with M=100ğ‘€100M=100 clients. Once again, we used a symmetric Dirichlet distribution to generate two datasets for every client. In particular, for each label yğ‘¦y we sampled two vectors pysubscriptğ‘ğ‘¦p_{y} and pyâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¦â€²p_{y}^{\prime} from a Dirichlet distribution of order M=100ğ‘€100M=100 and parameter Î±=0.3ğ›¼0.3\alpha=0.3. Then, for client mğ‘šm, we generated two datasets ğ’®msubscriptğ’®ğ‘š\mathcal{S}_{m} and ğ’®mâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ’®â€²ğ‘š\mathcal{S}^{\prime}_{m} by allocating py,msubscriptğ‘ğ‘¦ğ‘šp_{y,m} and py,mâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¦ğ‘šâ€²p_{y,m}^{\prime} fraction of all training instances of class yğ‘¦y.666 We always make sure that |ğ’®m|â‰¤|ğ’®mâ€²|subscriptğ’®ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptğ’®â€²ğ‘š|\mathcal{S}_{m}|\leq|\mathcal{S}^{\prime}_{m}|. Both ğ’®msubscriptğ’®ğ‘š\mathcal{S}_{m} and ğ’®mâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ’®â€²ğ‘š\mathcal{S}^{\prime}_{m} are partitioned into training and test sets following the original CIFAR training/test data split. Half of the training set obtained from ğ’®msubscriptğ’®ğ‘š\mathcal{S}_{m} is stored in the datastore, while the rest is further partitioned into t0subscriptğ‘¡0t_{0} batches ğ’®m(0),â€¦,ğ’®m(t0âˆ’1)superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘š0â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¡01\mathcal{S}_{m}^{(0)},\dots,\mathcal{S}_{m}^{(t_{0}-1)}. These batches are the new samples arriving at client mğ‘šm. Similarly, ğ’®mâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘šâ€²\mathcal{S}_{m}^{\prime} is partitioned into Tâˆ’t0ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¡0T-t_{0} equally sized batches. FigureÂ 14 shows the evaluation of the test accuracy across time. If clients do not update their datastores, there is a significant drop in accuracy as soon as the distribution changes at t0=50subscriptğ‘¡050t_{0}=50. If datastore are updated using FIFO, we observe some random fluctuations for the accuracy for t<t0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0t<t_{0}, as repository changes affect the kNN predictions. While accuracy inevitably drops for t=t0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0t=t_{0}, it then increases as datastores are progressively populated by instances from the new distributions. Once all samples from the previous distributions are evicted, the accuracy settles around a new value (higher or lower than the one for t<t0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0t<t_{0} depending on the difference between the new and the old distributions). If clients keep adding new samples to their datastores (the â€œconcatenateâ€ strategy), results are similar, but 1)Â accuracy increases for t<t0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0t<t_{0} as the quality of kNN predictors improves for larger datastores, 2) accuracy increases also for t>t0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0t>t_{0}, but at a slower pace than what observed under FIFO, as samples from the old distribution are never evicted.
